newsitem.title: USA: Ohio bill calls for $1.1 bln school bond program.
newsitem.headline: Ohio bill calls for $1.1 bln school bond program.

text.p: An Ohio lawmaker has introduced a bill to create a $1.1 billion bond program for school capital improvements by changing the state's regulations on the pricing and distribution of beer and wine.

State Rep. Gene Krebs, R-Camdem, proposed the adoption of a moderately deregulated system for beer and wine of no minimum mark ups or minimum prices along with a set increase in the excise tax. He said the plan would raise $113 million a year in tax revenue on beer and wine, $73 million more than is currently being collected.
Those funds would be used to back $1.1 billion of bonds for school capital projects, according to synopsis of Krebs' bill.
As for how school districts could access the bond program, Krebs proposed using a Tax Effort Index he unveiled last month.

The index, which is based on a formula that considers a school district's rate of self-imposed taxation along with its income level and property valuation, is aimed at identifying districts in need of state assistance.
Under Krebs' bill, school districts' ranking in the index would be the first criteria for qualifying for the bond program.

The bill also includes a a five percent reduction in the personal property inventory tax, dropping the rate to 20 percent. The tax proposal would result in a revenue loss of about $22 million for counties and about $51 million for school districts, according to the bill's synopsis.
